title.rendered: “Can I ask you a question?”… This is how the Facebook scam begins

content.rendered:
“Do you think you can earn money online? Who wants to earn more than 100,000 pesos a month?” a young man in a suit shouts from a platform and unleashes the euphoria of those attending a so-called economics seminar that more It looks like a motivational stand up show.

How did I get here? yes, you guess it, I answered the mysterious question that comes through Inbox on Facebook and I thought I could earn millions just by posting on the social network. But it turns out being rich costsminimum, 28 thousand pesos investment.

WE RECOMMEND YOU: Condusef Alert for more than ten types of financial fraud

This whole show is about a pyramid scheme in which you must distribute products from a company called bHip, ranging from energy drinks, makeup, proteins and even a female sexual enhancer; in addition to inviting people to invest.

According to what the project leaders said, bHip it was created by Terry LaCore in 2007 and arrived in Mexico two years ago; allegedly, Lacore is a businessman who held management positions in companies such as Amazon; Nevertheless, does not appear nothing in regards in Google.

A one hour show… for nothing

After answering the mechanized question and due to the curiosity generated by the few details that they give you on Facebook, I decided to take a risk and went to the meeting where they would solve all my doubts.

The meeting was in a building in the Del Valle neighborhood. In a room that had logos of social networks such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, as well as motivational phrases in English painted on the walls, about 100 people, most of them between 15 and 30 years old, were sitting listening to a motivational comedian who makes call omar stark.

Stark introduced himself as a project leader, welcomed us and congratulated us on being “weird” enough to accept an invitation from a stranger, then began to give us information about e-commerce using as examples companies like Uber and Amazon.

WE RECOMMEND YOU: Twitter user trolled his scammer and turned it into a melodrama

After an hour of screams, laughter and applause from the audience, Stark said the name of the company, but not how the project works; he mentioned that to know that you have to go to another boardwhose admission costs 100 pesosnot because it’s worth it, but because “what’s free you don’t take into account”.

After paying the 100 pesos, they summoned me to the party room Le Crillon Palace, located in the same neighborhood; There, about 60 people, all formally dressed, came to the front and told us the story of their lives as ninis, godínez, students, there was even a man who said he was a journalist and a woman who, according to her, was a judge, everyone stopped being poor and unhappy to become rich and free with the project, or so they said.

People went on to give their testimonials one after another for three hours, until Stark took the stage and started talking about the products of bHip; he explained that you have to distribute and promote the merchandise on social networks, but we had to know them, so he gave us a taste of Blue, an “energy powder” that dissolves in water and tastes horrible

So how does the scam work?

To be a “professional dealer” and make a profit, you must pay a kit that costs 30 thousand pesos, includes 30 boxes of products and a website for promotions through social networks. Believe it or not, the next day of the meeting, four people had already paid.

They explained to me that I should create fake facebook profiles to send at least a thousand friend requests and daily messages to strangers; as well as calling everyone I know, to promote the products; “If you work hard you can recover your investment in up to three hours,” they told me.

However, it is not the only way to generate income, this is where the pyramid scheme comes in, because with the same fake profiles you have to contact people, with a script that they give you, to invite them to join the project; for each person who decides to invest, you will earn a percentage; In addition, 10 percent of what your referrals sell, that is, a pyramid scheme.

On its website, the National Commission for the Protection and Defense of Users of Financial Services (Condusef) explains that in pyramid schemes, “whoever is at the top of the pyramid invites two people who, in turn, recruit two others, and so on.”

In the end, whoever gets more people to invest wins more money; then I discovered that there is no freedom, because even when you are already a “professional”, you must continue going to the talks, tell your testimony and to sell you have to be in the offices.

After four days, I decided not to return anymore while listening to the same testimony; When I left I saw that there were another 100 people waiting to enter to discover how to earn money using social networks; I walked to the subway with my anger on my back, for the lost time.
